content: Hello. Is there a team / someone I could ask how to unsquat a crate someone took for nothing? I have a project I’d like to put on that name but it’s taken for nothing. The documentation on that crate points to a Rick Roll video. https://docs.rs/crate/nuance/0.0.0

https://github.com/iqlusioninc/crates they’ve put this as page to show that they maintain those libs, but it’s a lie — they have ~150 crates uploaded, most of them are just namesquats; I’m so annoyed with this…
Maybe get in touch with someone from the crates.io team?

Also, relevant bits of the crates.io policies:

Using an automated tool to claim ownership of a large number of package names is not permitted. We reserve the right to block traffic or revoke ownership of any package we determine to have been claimed by an automated tool.

We do not have any policies to define 'squatting', and so will not hand over ownership of a package for that reason.
inb4 Cargo adds explicit support for npm-style @scopes. Then you can have, say, @rustcrypto/md5 and @rustcrypto/sha1 crates (and Cargo would import those as md5 and sha1 by default).

I don’t think people should ask a namesquatter to “gently stop squatting”
you shouldn’t squat in the first place
Right, the feature I mentioned isn't there yet, but I want that feature enough that I'd be happy to implement it and submit a pull request if needed.
@Chris Jester-Young you may be interested in https://internals.rust-lang.org/t/pre-rfc-packages-as-optional-namespaces/13059
current status is at the bottom: https://internals.rust-lang.org/t/pre-rfc-packages-as-optional-namespaces/13059/68
Thanks!

So, I read through Manish's pre-RFC. That's certainly one way to solve the problem I have in mind, in that you could have digest/md5 and digest/sha1. But the default package names of digest_md5 and digest_sha1 is a bit gross.

When I specify @rustcrypto/md5 or @rustcrypto/sha1 in my proposal, I am expressing a disinterest (at least by default) in using the top-level md5 and sha1 crates. I already do this in my Cargo.toml files, using sha1 = { package = "sha-1" }. This already signals my disintent to use the top-level sha1 crate, and that anywhere I use sha1 in my code, I only want to use the genuine crate as published by RustCrypto.

That's the use case I'm trying to facilitate. :-)
interesting @Chris Jester-Young , thanks a lot
what are the blocking parts of the PR for that? adoption? since it’s a pre-RFC, I guess it’s not acted people actually want it?
@phaazon it has a summary at the end, it's waiting for the author to post an RFC
please read the links :(
I was about to :smile:

It frustrates me that what is typically such a great community can be plagued by bad actors name-squatting and crate trolling.

I just came across this user today: https://crates.io/users/kumacodes

They have 22 useless crates with some pretty common and useful names. Totally and completely empty for 6 months. Their GitHub profile has 0 activity and no way to contact them.

I tried to file an issue but was swiftly told that an RFC would have to be made in order to change the crates.io policy. Is there any chance that the crates.io team would be amenable to some sort of policy change, or would I just be spinning my wheels trying to put out an RFC?

@Ben Reeves it has been discussed at length, both on GitHub and internals.r-l.o, but the crates.io team seems to be completely against any squatting-related policy, including asking nicely "please don't squat on crate names".
big damn :/
It seems like a sensible policy could be "if you provide no method of contact, then your crate can be removed." That isn't even necessarily a squatting policy.

I don’t want you to feel that anyone’s denying that something you could call squatting is happening. Its clear that most - maybe even all - of the crates claimed by these users will never be used for useful projects, and its clear that the names chosen were chosen because they are obvious names for projects. But I say nothing has changed because the policy was made in full awareness that this sort of thing would happen, and the fact that it has happened doesn’t make me feel like we have any reason to revise the policy.
(from https://internals.rust-lang.org/t/pre-rfc-formal-squatting-policy-on-crates-io/11302)

I think one issue is that every time this comes up, someone asks for namespacing, which is IMO a different, almost orthogonal concern. And there's a pre-RFC for that: https://github.com/Manishearth/namespacing-rfc/blob/main/0000-packages-as-optional-namespaces.md.

By the way, I don't have any relationship to the crates.io team, so I'm not sure quoting me on GitHub proves anything. That was just my impression from reading that thread and others on the same subject. (Although the comment I pasted above is from an ex-crates.io team member)
